China's stock market fell overnight by 6.5 percent, but that may turn out to be just a small dip.
The Chinese stock market has doubled in value so far this year and that pace is prompting warnings that the market may be overheating.
Why should Americans care?
Well, here to tell us is John Dimsdale of MARKETPLACE.
And before we get to that question, John, first, why the overnight drop?
Well, the government in Beijing knows the stock market is overheated.
It's really been quite remarkable.

So far this year there are 300,000 new brokerage accounts established every day, and the managers of China's economy is trying to let some of the air out of the bubble without making the whole thing collapse.
So they've announced a surprise tripling of the stock trading tax just last night.

And that triggered a big sell-off, the second biggest drop in a decade, exceeded only by a nearly nine percent slowdown in February when the government also tried to tap on the breaks to cool off what Alan Greenspan warned just last week is another case of irrational exuberance.
Well, so this isn't exactly a bubble bursting then, is it?
No, no, and probably won't be happening, at least anytime soon.
There's still plenty of enthusiasm for the stock market among small investors in China, according to Asia scholar Jacques deLisle at the Foreign Policy Research Institute.
These people don't have too many other options.
Bank interest rates are low.
They don't want to sit on the sidelines while prices spiral upwards.
And the Chinese market has remained relatively closed to institutional investors who otherwise would be, I think, somewhat more balanced and sober investors.
Okay, John, now to that question why should we care?
What danger does an overheated Chinese stock market pose to Americans?
Well, as you know, the global economy and the U.S.
economy in particular has become very intertwined with China's economy, but not necessarily with the stock market in China.
There's a difference.
Even the Chinese economy itself doesn't depend as much on the stock market, even though there's a lot of small investors in it.
That's probably because, as Jacques deLisle said, big institutional investors are putting their money elsewhere.
Also, U.S.
investors have mostly steered clear of the relatively unregulated Chinese stock market.
If you're interested in investing in China's economic boom, you'd be better advise to put your money in peripheral stock markets, like Hong Kong or Singapore or in the U.S.
companies that do a lot of business in China.
So last night's drop in China's stock market didn't seem to faze the U.S.

stock market today, unlike that tumble back in February, and that's seen as evidence that, you know, there is a buffer between global markets and the very volatile Chinese stock market, at least for now.
That's Brooks Pallen (ph).
He says when he was a kid, there was an expectation of eating together.
Oh, it's utter rhetoric.
We have not at all done even the small amount--and I would emphasize small amount--that was done in the Clinton years around bringing peripheral people into the work force.

There has been very--in fact, we've cut education, Ed, to the point that one of the bridges that people fought, if you go back to Humphrey Hawkins, you go back--now we're going back a generation or so, but the community college would have been the place where a displaced worker would re-tool themselves.
So you used to be an autoworker and now you're going to be something else.
Where do you learn those skills?
Well, community colleges have been cut.
So educational institutions are being cut at a time when the American work force that is non-college-educated desperately need re-tooling.
In addition, the college-educated work force, quite frankly, is not also having the kind of success that it would like to have.
And you've got about a third of all Americans who are doing uncommonly well.
Yeah.

Yeah.

But the majority of Americans are finding their wages relatively stagnant.
Yeah.

This is SCIENCE FRIDAY from NPR News.
I'm Ira Flatow.
This week, paleontologists from all over the world are meeting in England to share their fossil finds.

They're presenting over 100 papers and posters over there on all kinds of creatures and their lifestyles, from the structure of early feathers to the eating habits of giant, swimming reptiles - things that would probably fit the definition of a sea monster.
Another one of the papers would be familiar if you're a regular listening, and that is the life history of a baby mammoth found in Siberia, something we talked about on the show not too long ago.
And joining us now from the annual meeting of the Society of Vertebrate Paleontology is a reporter who has sifted through the science and is here to talk about it.
Sid Perkins is the earth sciences and paleontology writer at Science News in Washington.
He joins us by phone from Bristol.
Welcome to SCIENCE FRIDAY, Sid.
Happy to be with you.
Thank you.
Yesterday, Nature rushed out a paper presented at the conference on a feathered dino.
Tell us why they did that and why they rushed that out.
Well, yeah, this has made quite a splash in the news today, and deservedly so.
This was big news on a number of fronts.

The paper was given this morning, the oral presentation, and it had to do with the discovery of a peacock-sized, feathered dinosaur excavated from Northeastern China, which is the source of so many feathered dinosaurs in recent years.

This creature, however, is from rocks estimated to be between 151 million and 161 million years old, which is interesting because it predates Archaeopteryx, which scientists consider to be the first bird, by, you know, between one and 11 million years.
So this creature has the oldest feathers that have been found in the fossil record.

And that's important because many of the more recent feathered dinosaurs had these simpler types of feathers than Archaeopteryx, even though they were millions of years younger, and some scientists had cast doubt that these structures were even feathers.
But this newly described creature has the same sort of structure seen on those more recent dinosaurs.
So, you know, time is not out of order anymore.
(Soundbite of music)
So it sort of strengthens the idea that dinosaurs were birds.
